Graphical abstract The in-situ formed V-Co alloy nanoparticles during conversion reaction thermodynamically reduces the formation energy barrier of the reaction pathway, thus enhances the bidirectional redox kinetics of NaPSs and improve the reversibility of VS2 conversion reaction. Sodium-based storage devices based on conversion-type metal sulfide anodes have attracted great attention due to their multivalent ion redox reaction ability. However, they also suffer from sodium polysulfides (NaPSs) shuttling problems during the sluggish Na+ redox process, leading to “voltage failure” and rapid capacity decay. Herein, a metal cobalt-doping vanadium disulfide (Co-VS2) is proposed to simultaneously accelerate the electrochemical reaction of VS2 and enhance the bidirectional redox of soluble NaPSs. It is found that the strong adsorption of NaPSs by V-Co alloy nanoparticles formed in situ during the conversion reaction of Co-VS2 can effectively inhibit the dissolution and shuttle of NaPSs, and thermodynamically reduce the formation energy barrier of the reaction path to effectively drive the complete conversion reaction, while the metal transition of Co elements enhances reconversion kinetics to achieve high reversibility. Moreover, Co-VS2 also produce abundant sulfur vacancies and unsaturated sulfur edge defects, significantly improve ionic/electron diffusion kinetics. Therefore, the Co-VS2 anode exhibits ultrahigh rate capability (562 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1), high initial coulombic efficiency (≈90%) and 12,000 ultralong cycle life with capacity retention of 90% in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), as well as impressive energy/power density (118 Wh kg−1/31,250 W kg−1) and over 10,000 stable cycles in sodium-ion hybrid capacitors (SIHCs). Moreover, the pouch cell-type SIHC displays a high-energy density of 102 Wh kg−1 and exceed 600 stable cycles. This work deepens the understanding of the electrochemical reaction mechanism of conversion-type metal sulfide anodes and provides a valuable solution to the shuttling of NaPSs in SIBs and SIHCs. Keywords Sodium-ion batteries Sodium-ion hybrid capacitors Pouch cells Vanadium disulfide Shuttle effect 1 Introduction In the past few decades, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have achieved great success as energy storage devices for portable electronic products [1,2]. However, with the rapid development of sustainable energy (such as solar energy, wind energy, and tidal energy), the demand for large-scale, environmentally friendly, and safe energy storage systems is explosive growth [3–5]. Increasing concerns about the scarcity and safety of lithium resources have promoted the development of other non-lithium energy storage devices [6]. Sodium-based energy storage devices, including sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) and sodium-ion hybrid capacitors (SIHCs), are considered as a useful supplement to LIBs in the field of large-scale energy storage and electric vehicles due to the similar properties of sodium and lithium, abundant sodium resources, high safety and good energy density [7–9]. Nevertheless, compared with Li+ (0.76 Å, 6.9 g mol−1), Na+ (1.02 Å, 23 g mol−1) has a larger radius and higher molar mass, resulting in unsatisfactory performance of commercial LIB electrode materials (such as graphite) [10]. Therefore, it is urgent to develop advanced high-performance anode materials to meet the growing large-scale application requirements of sodium-based energy storage devices in the future. Layered transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), (VS2, MoS2, WS2, SnS2, et al) have attracted great interest and been widely used in energy storage materials due to their open two-dimensional layered structure similar to graphite, abundant resources, low cost, and high theoretical capacity [11–13]. However, the rate performance and long cycle stability of TMD anodes in practical applications still face severe challenges. Traditionally, it is believed that the large volume change and slow Na+ transport kinetics during the sodiation/desodiation process are the key factors hindering the cycling stability of TMD anodes [14–16]. However, recent studies have gradually found that the shuttle of sodium polysulfide (NaPSs) is another key factor affecting their performance [17]. It has been reported that soluble NaPSs exists in the process of forming the final products (Na2S) in the Na-TMDs system [18]. The escape of NaPSs in the electrolyte means the waste of active materials, resulting in rapid capacity decay and poor rate performance. In addition, due to the material segregation and poor conductivity of Na2S during the charging process, they will irreversibly transform into S, rather than the original TMDs. Therefore, S gradually replaces TMDs as the active material for storing Na+, and finally similar to the Na-S battery system [19–21]. In the previous research work, it also observed that the dissolution and escape of polysulfide intermediates caused the occurrence of shuttle effect, which showed an abnormal charging state with the voltage failure issue during cycles, further leading to the cell failure and cycle life termination [22,23]. Based on this, shuttle inhibition of NaPSs is the key to improve the stability of TMDs in long cycling and the retention of high specific capacity. The electrochemical processes of TMDs are multi-step sequential processes, and the Na+ intercalation/deintercalation process is accompanied by a complex process of NaPSs intermediate generation, transfer and conversion. Different from Na-S batteries, the metal elements in TMDs also participate in the conversion reaction process during the electrochemical reaction process, and there are also changes in the valence of the active substance, so it also involves the transfer and transmission process of the reaction between charge/ion and metal elements. Therefore, it is necessary to simultaneously enhance the electrochemical reaction kinetics of active metal elements and the ability to accelerate the conversion reaction of NaPSs during the Na+ intercalation and deintercalation of TMDs, so as to achieve the purpose of inhibiting the shuttle effect of intermediates in the dissolved state, solving the voltage failure and enhancing the electrochemical reaction kinetics of TMDs. In this work, taking vanadium disulfide (VS2) as the research object, different from most physical semiconducting TMD materials, as a kind of 1T-phase TMDs, VS2 exhibits inherent metallic behavior and high electronic conductivity. During charging and discharging, there are more conversion reaction steps in the transition of vanadium elemental from tetravalent to zero-valent, which means that it is more likely to occur the dissolution and shuttle phenomenon of NaPSs intermediates. Based on the above theory, a strategy of heterogeneous atom doping catalysis to accelerate the bidirectional redox of soluble NaPSs and induce the regulation of metal ion conversion reaction process is proposed. It has been proved that Co doping promotes the conversion of soluble Na2S x to insoluble Na2S. The uniformly distributed V-Co alloy nanoparticles formed during the conversion reaction can effectively accelerate the electron transport, reduce the energy barrier of the relatively inert Na2S conversion, and prevent the agglomeration/coarsening of V mental nanoparticles during the conversion process, thereby enhancing the reversibility of the conversion reaction. In addition, rich sulfur vacancies and unsaturated sulfur edge defects can be simultaneously developed by Co-doping, that significantly improve ionic and electronic diffusion kinetics. Benefiting from rapid ion/charge transfer and efficient conversion reaction in the complete cycle, Co-VS2 exhibits impressive high-rate and ultralong-life cycle performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of materials Co-doped VS2 nanosheets were prepared by solvothermal method. Concretely, (2−x) mmol vanadyl acetylacetonate (VO(acac)2), x mmol cobaltous acetylacetonate (Co(acac)2) (x = 0.06, 0.10, 0.20, and 0.40) and 8 mmol thioacetamide (TAA) were dissolved in 30 mL N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). After magnetic stirring for 1 h, the mixed solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was kept at 200 °C for 24 h, then naturally cooled down to room temperature. The black precipitates were collected by a centrifugal separation technique and it was washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times and then freeze-dried for 24 h. These Co-doped VS2 with different Co doping concentrations were named as 3%Co-VS2, 5%Co-VS2, 10%Co-VS2, and 20%Co-VS2. For comparative study, the pure VS2 was also synthesized via the same process without adding Co(acac)2. 2.2 Preparation of Na2S6 solution Sulfur and Na2S (molar ratio of 5:1) were dissolved in 1,2-Dimethoxyethane (DME) and stirred at 60 °C for 24 h in an argon-filled glove box to obtain a dark black solution. The solution was diluted to light yellow (5 mmol L−1) before use. 2.3 Material characterization The morphology and crystal structure of samples were characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi SU8010) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI TALOS F200X). The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was collected by X Pert PRO MPD diffractometer under Cu K α radiation. Raman spectra were obtained by ThermoScientific Dxr2 xi spectrometer with 532 nm excitation wavelength. The elemental composition and chemical state of the sample surface were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, Al K α radiation). The BET test was performed using a specific surface and porosity analyzer (Micromeritics ASAP 2460) to evaluate the surface area and pore size distribution. Thermal decomposition process of samples were measured by differential scanning calorimeter (DSC, TA Q20) at a rate of 5 °C min−1 from room temperature to 300 °C in N2 atmosphere. The content of Co element was measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Agilent 5110). The sulfur vacancies in the samples were analyzed by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR, Bruker EMXnano). 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical properties were carried out by using CR2032 cointype cells, in which metallic sodium (diameter: 15.6 mm) was chosen as the counter electrode, glass ber (GF/D) was used as a separator and 1 M NaPF6 in DME was used as the electrolyte. The working electrodes were prepared by mixing the electrode materials, acetylene black, and PVDF in a ratio of 7:2:1 by mass ratio in N-methyl pyrrolidinone solvent. The composite slurry was coated on Cu foil. After being dried at 65 °C in a vacuum for 12 h, the electrode sheets were cut into round pieces with a diameter of 14 mm. The mass loading of the active material was 1.2–1.5 mg cm−2. Galvanostatic charge and discharge measurements were performed on a Neware battery test system (BTS-5 V-20 mA) within a voltage window of 0.3–3.0 V vs. Na+/Na. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was tested by Shanghai ChenHua electrochemical workstation (CHI760E). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were performed in the frequency range of 10−2–105 Hz. Testing the conductivity of samples using a four-probe meter (FT-330). The SIHC device was fabricated using the pre-sodiated 3%Co-VS2 anode and the AC (YP-80F) cathode together with the above electrolyte. The mass ratio of anode to cathode was set to be 1:1 to 1:8. Before being assembled into SIHCs, the anode was assembled into a half cell and discharged to 0.3 V after three cycles at a current density of 0.1 A g−1. The cathode was prepared by dissolving 70 wt% AC, 20 wt% acetylene black, and 10 wt% PVDF binder in NMP and then coating on Al foil. The electrolyte added for each coin cell is 200 μL. 2.5 SIHC pouch cell assembly SIHC pouch cells were assembled with the pre-sodiated 3%Co-VS2 as anode, the AC as cathode, polypropylene film as the separator, and vacuum-sealed Al-plastic film as packaging. The dimension of the both electrode was 58 mm × 45 mm. Among them, the mass loading of the active material on the anode is 72–80 mg, and the mass loading of the active material on the cathode is 220–235 mg. The energy density of the SIHC pouch cells was calculated based on the total mass of active material on the anode and cathode. For SIHC pouch cells, 1 M NaPF6 in DME was used as the electrolyte. The volume of electrolyte is 2 mL. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material characterizations Co-VS2 samples were prepared by one-step solvothermal method (see experimental section). XRD analysis was used to study the phase structure of the prepared samples (Fig. 1 a). When the Co doping amount is 3%, 5%, and 10%, these main diffraction peaks at 32.7°, 35.7°, 57.1°, and 58.3° shows similar diffraction peaks with VS2 (JCPDS: 89-1640), and no other impurity peaks are observed. When the Co doping amount increased to 20%, new diffraction peaks appeared at 54.7° and 62.7°, indicating the formation of a new phase of CoS2 (JCPDS: 19-0362). It is worth noting that the diffraction peaks representing the (001) crystal plane in each sample are obviously shifted from 15.4° to 9.6° (according to the Bragg equation, the interplanar spacing is extended from 0.576 to 0.922 nm). This is because small molecules/ions can be embedded in the interlayer during the solvothermal reaction [24]. The increased spacing is consistent with the size of NH4+ (∼0.35 nm) [25]. FTIR, DSC, and XPS results further confirmed that the intercalated species was NH4 + (Fig. S1). After thermal treatment at 400 °C, the NH4 + can be effectively evaporated from the VS2 nanosheets. It is observed that all the diffraction peaks of the annealed VS2 sample match well with those of the pristine VS2 (Fig. S2). Besides, the real contents of Co element in 3%Co-VS2, 5%Co-VS2, and 10%Co-VS2 are determined to be 1.46%, 2.05%, and 4.58%, respectively, by ICP-OES (Fig. S3). The actual content of Co element is lower than the theoretical analysis value, indicating that only part of Co can be successfully doped during the reaction. The Raman spectrum of as-prepared samples in the range of 100–1200 cm−1 is shown in Fig. 1b. The characteristic peaks at ∼284 and ∼406 cm−1 are attributed to the in-plane E 1g and out-of-plane A 1g vibration modes of VS2, respectively. These two peaks at ∼141 and ∼993 cm−1 are caused by the bending vibration of the skeleton of the layered structure. In addition, the vibration peaks at ∼505 and ∼674 cm−1 correspond to the Co-S bond in 20%Co-VS2, which is responsible for the CoS2 new phase. The surface chemical compositions and valence states of as-prepared samples were determined by XPS measurement. The survey spectra confirm the existence of Co element in 3%Co-VS2 (Fig. S4). The high-resolution of Co 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 1c) shows two peaks at 781.1 and 796.2 eV, corresponding to 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 orbitals of Co2+. As shown in Fig. 1(d), the V 2p spectrum of VS2 shows two prominent peaks at 516.6 and 524.0 eV, corresponding to V4+ 2p 3/2 and V4+ 2p 1/2. However, the V 2p spectrum of 3%Co-VS2 shows four characteristic peaks, corresponding to V4+ (516.8 and 524.2 eV) and V2+ (513.6 and 521.2 eV). The presence of V2+ may be due to the presence of unsaturated sulfur defects at the edges of the crystal structure as well as sulfur vacancies inside the crystal due to Co-doping [26]. When compared with VS2, the peaks of V4+ for 3%Co-VS2 show slight shifts to higher binding energies. This is because the electronegativity of the doped cobalt atom is larger than that of vanadium, resulting in a lower electron cloud density around vanadium [27]. Two peaks located at 161.2 and 162.4 eV in the S 2p XPS spectrum of VS2 are assigned to the lattice sulfur (S2−), which is the in-plane S2− species of VS2 (Fig. 1e). In comparison, 3%Co-VS2 exhibits additional peaks at 163.6 and 164.8 eV. Those are attributed to the bridging disulfide ligand (S2 2−). The presence of S2 2− ligands are widely regarded as unsaturated sulfur edge defects [28,29]. In addition, the S2− binding energy representing the V–S bond in 3% Co-VS2 is positively shifted by about 0.2 eV compared to that of VS2. This may be due to the presence of sulfur vacancies, where the transfer of electrons from sulfide to vacancies would reduce the equilibrium electron cloud density, endowing the enhancement of the binding energies [30]. The EPR spectra (Fig. 1f) show a strong signal at 2.0037 for Co-VS2, confirming the presence of abundant sulfur vacancies. And the peak is stronger as the doping concentration rises, indicating a higher concentration of sulfur vacancies in the material. However, excessive sulfur vacancy concentration may lead to defect agglomeration to form clustered vacancy that will produce deep trapping levels and degrade the electronic properties [31]. Therefore, the construction of moderate vacancies in the crystal structure to provide efficient vacancy diffusion is expected to significantly improve ion transport. SEM and TEM were used to observe the morphological and microstructural characteristics of the as-prepared samples. As shown in Fig. S5, VS2 is a nanosheet morphological with a size of about 200–400 nm. These nanosheets are closely packed and agglomerated seriously. Comparatively, after Co doping, it still has the same nanosheet structure as VS2. However, careful observation found that these nanosheets alternately bent and grew, and the agglomeration phenomenon is significantly improved. We further compare these peak intensities of (001)/(011) for the four Co-VS2 samples (Fig. S6). The I (001)/I (011) value increases from 3.41 of pure VS2 to 6.19 of 10%Co-VS2, which means that VS2 grows preferentially along the a and b lattices with smaller surface energy, and finally forms a larger and thinner nanosheet structure. The growth tendency will cause the bending growth of VS2 nanosheets. With the increase of Co doping amount, it is observed that these curved nanosheets tended to agglomerate. The reason is that more Co2+ and V4+ species in the solution would react with S2− species to generate 2D cores, and then Co and V species in the solution can continuously interact with the primary 2D cores from different directions, further forming nanosheets that intersect in different directions and gradually agglomerate. By virtue of the fluffy structure, relatively higher specific surface areas of 3%Co-VS2 (82.4 m2 g−1), 5%Co-VS2 (80.9 m2 g−1), and 10%Co-VS2 (76.2 m2 g−1) than VS2 (13.8 m2 g−1) are confirmed by the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms, as shown in Fig. S7. In addition, the pore size distribution data (Table S1) further indicate that Co-VS2 contains a larger pore volume and average pore size than those of VS2, thereby favoring charge–transfer reaction and diffusion of electrolyte. TEM image (Fig. 1g) indicates that these nanosheets are irregularly arranged, and the curly structure forms rich electrolyte infiltration and ion transport channels. Fig. 1(h) shows a typical layered structure with a measured lattice spacing of 0.92 nm (inset in Fig. 1h) corresponding to the (001) plane of 3%Co-VS2. The SAED pattern shows diffraction rings attributed to the 3%Co-VS2 (002), (011), and (110) crystal planes, as shown in Fig. S8. In addition, the observed discontinuous lattice fringes along the lamellar dimension in HRTEM confirmed the existence of unsaturated sulfur edges defects. These defects are mainly distributed on the lateral and interlayer sides of the (001) crystal surface, which can provide new ion transport channels and active sites. The EDS mappings show the presence and uniform distribution of V, Co, and S elements (Fig. 1i). 3.2 Na+ storage mechanism analyses In-situ XRD, ex-situ XPS, HRTEM, and SAED characterizations were performed to investigate the different Na+ storage mechanisms in 3%Co-VS2 and VS2. Fig. 2 (a) shows the in-situ XRD contour patterns during the first charge-discharge cycle. When the electrode is discharged from 2.4 to 1.0 V, the (001), (002), and (011) planes for 3%Co-VS2 gradually weaken, demonstrating transition from VS2 to Na x VCoS2 (0＜x ≤ 2) (JCPDS:04-001-6162). With further discharge from 1.0 to 0.3 V, the diffraction peak color of Na x VCoS2 disappeared, accompany with new significant color observed at 38.9, 42.2, and 47.6°, corresponding to the generation of Na2S (220) lattice plane (JCPDS: 00-023-0441), the metal V0 (110) lattice plane (JCPDS: 97-004-3420), and the metal Co0 (101) lattice plane (JCPDS:00-005-0727), respectively. It means Co-VS2 undergoes a transformation reaction with Na+ to produce both V0, Co0, and Na2S. By comparison, the similar intercalation and conversion reactions also appear in VS2. However, for the charging process, VS2 and 3%Co-VS2 have different variations process. For 3%Co-VS2, a large amount of V0/Co0/Na2S is reversibly converted to Na x VCoS2 during charging process, and then Na x VCoS2 is further de-sodiumated to form Co-VS2. Differently, for VS2, even charging to 3.0 V, the characteristic peak of VS2 has not appeared, implying the irreversible structural evolution. Instead, the diffraction peaks of (222), (040), (044), and (331) crystal planes representing S appeared at 23.1°, 27.8°, 31.5°, and 33.3° (JCPDS:00-008-0247) (Fig. S9). This indicates that during the subsequent charging process, Na2S and V are irreversibly converted to V and S instead of the original VS2, in agreement with previous reports in other sulfide anodes [32–34]. In addition, to verify the effect of NH4 + on the above electrochemical reaction mechanism, the in-situ XRD of annealed VS2 during the first cycle was further tested, as shown in Fig. S10. These results show that NH4 + has no effect on the electrochemical reaction mechanism of VS2. This significant difference indicates that cobalt doping plays a key role in the reversible conversion of charge and discharge of VS2. To examine the chemical state changes of the electrode elements, ex situ XPS test was performed chosen 3%Co-VS2 and VS2 electrodes at the pristine, fully discharged, and charged states during the 1st cycle, respectively. Fig. S11(a) shows high-resolution V 2p spectra. Compared with the pristine state, there are low-valent vanadium (V3+) and metal vanadium (V0) in the V 2p spectrum under fully discharged state. When charged to 3.0 V, the peak of low-valent vanadium disappeared and the V 2p spectrum returned to the initial state, indicating that Na+ was reversibly extracted from 3%Co-VS2. XPS spectra of Na 1s further confirmed the reversible Na+ extraction (Fig. S12). The Co 2p spectra could be deconvoluted into two peaks at 781.1 and 796.2 eV, corresponding to 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 orbitals of Co2+. In fully discharged, the peak intensities of the Co2+ 2p 3/2 and Co2+ 2p 1/2 are weakened along with the appearance of two new peaks located at 778.2 and 793.0 eV, which could be well-ascribed to Co0 2p 3/2 and Co0 2p 1/2, respectively (Fig. S11b). As a result, the conversion reaction process resulted in the formation of uniformly dispersed V-Co alloy nanoparticles. In addition, the formation of V-Co alloys nanoparticles was further confirmed by TEM and SEAD. At a fully sodiated state of 0.3 V, HRTEM image in Fig. 2(b) contains several nanocrystal areas with crystal lattices of 0.23, 0.2, 0.16, 0.14, 0.22, and 0.19 nm, which can be attributed to (220), (311), and (400) plane of Na2S, and (220), (111), and (200) plane of V-Co alloy nanoparticles. The EDS elemental mapping images and corresponding diffraction rings of SAED result further confirm the co-existence of Na2S and V-Co alloy nanoparticles at this stage (Figs. S13 and S14a). At the full de-sodiation state of 3.0 V, both HRTEM and SAED results suggest the existence of 3%Co-VS2 (Fig. 2c and Fig. S14b), confirming the highly reversible conversion process between Na2S and V-Co alloy nanoparticles. Based on the above discussion, the efficient reversible conversion path in discharging and charging process for Co-VS2 is illustrated in Fig. 2(d), which includes intercalation and reversible conversion reaction: Co-VS2 ⇋ Na x VCoS2 ⇋ V-Co/Na2S. 3.3 Na+ storage performance and DFT calculation It is generally believed that the rapid capacity decay of TMDs electrodes is caused by the structural degradation caused by the volume change of active materials during repeated charging and discharging. In fact, for conversion-type metal sulfide anodes, the polysulfide shuttle effect is usually defined as another important factor for the rapid capacity decay of sodium ion batteries [35,36]. So far, the polysulfide shuttle effect in alkali metal ion batteries has not been fully demonstrated due to the complexity of the relevant reactions and many factors. To verify the presence of polysulfide during charging and discharging, an in-situ battery with Na counter electrode and VS2/3%Co-VS2 electrode was carried out (1 M NaPF6 in DME as electrolyte, current density of 5 A g−1). As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the color of electrolyte with VS2 electrode is observed to be light yellow after 300 cycles, indicating the dissolution of NaPSs in the DME electrolyte. However, the color of electrolyte with 3%Co-VS2 electrode is almost unchanged after 300 cycles, indicating the disappearance of soluble NaPSs. The composition of polysulfides during charge and discharge is further revealed by UV–vis spectra (Fig. 3b). The electrolyte with VS2 electrode has obvious absorption peaks near the wavelengths of 210 and 340 nm, corresponding to Na2S6 and Na2S4 species [37]. Comparably, the absorption intensity of the electrolyte with 3%Co-VS2 electrode is greatly reduced. These results prove that the electrochemical reaction process of VS2 is accompanied by the dissolution of NaPSs during the cycle, and this sluggish electrochemical reaction process inevitably leads to the loss of active substances. The introduction of cobalt metal can enhance the adsorption and conversion kinetic of NaPSs, thus greatly alleviating the dissolution of NaPSs. Furthermore, the electrochemical performance of as-prepared samples is comprehensively analyzed. For comparison, the second CV cycles of VS2 and Co doped VS2 at 0.5 mV s−1 are firstly exhibited in Fig. 3(c). They show the similar shape in CV curves but different peak current intensities. From the characterization results of in-situ XRD in Fig. 2(a), it can be seen that these reduction peaks at 1.94 and 1.54 V represent the sodium intercalation reaction, while the reduction peak at 0.8 V represents the conversion reaction of the intercalation compound. For the subsequent anodic process, these anodic peaks at 1.54 and 2.14 V correspond to the reversible conversion reaction and the deintercalation of Na+ [38]. It can be seen from the strong peak intensity and wide peak area that Co-doped VS2 can significantly increase the intercalation and conversion reaction kinetics, and predicts that this process can provide more reversible capacity in comparison with VS2. Fig. 3(d) shows the first charge-discharge curve of the VS2 and Co-VS2 at 0.1 A g−1. The discharge/charge specific capacities of 3%Co-VS2 in the first cycle are 724 and 652 mA h g−1 with an initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 90%, which is greatly higher than the previously reported metal sulfide-based anode materials as presented in Fig. S15. The high ICE of the 3%Co-VS2 electrode may be related to the structural stability and the highly reversible Na+ charge storage process with few side reactions [39]. As seen in Fig. 3(e), the 3%Co-VS2 electrode outperforms rate capability compared with VS2, 5%Co-VS2, and 10%Co-VS2 electrodes. The reversible capacities of 3%Co-VS2 electrode are 614, 600, 599, 596, 584, and 562 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 1, 3, and 5 A g−1, respectively. This means that the appropriate concentration of Co doping can greatly enhance the electrochemical kinetics and greatly improve the rate performance. In addition, the corresponding charge/discharge curves of 3%Co-VS2 at different rates are shown in Fig. S16. The charge-discharge curves remain highly overlapped, showing excellent rate performance and small voltage polarization. Electrochemical performance for various reported VS2-based and other sulfide-based anodes for SIBs are compared (Fig. 3f and Table S2). The rate performance and cycle performance of the obtained 3%Co-VS2 stands out among those of SIBs anodes. The cycling performances of Co-VS2 and VS2 at a current density of 5 A g−1 are shown in Fig. 3(g) and Fig. S17. As previously discussed, the VS2 electrode suffers from rapid capacity decay at the beginning of the cycle due to irreversible conversion leading to polysulfide shuttling and poor structural stability. On the contrary, benefiting from Co doping, the shuttle effect of polysulfides in the electrode can be effectively suppressed, Co-VS2 exhibits better cycle stability. Among them, 3%Co-VS2 has a capacity retention rate of 90% (reversible capacity is 501 mA h g−1) after 12000 cycles, and the corresponding attenuation rate is ≈0.00083% per cycle. The CE remains almost at 100% after capacity stabilization, indicating that the electrochemical reactions of Na+ are highly reversible. In addition, the cycled batteries were disassembled in the glove box, and it was found that the surface of the glass fiber separator and the sodium sheet was obviously discolored due to the shuttle effect in the VS2 electrode. However, this phenomenon in the 3%Co-VS2 electrode is not so severe (Fig. S18), which is another strong evidence for the improvement of electrochemical adsorption between 3%Co-VS2 and NaPSs. All these results confirm that the polysulfide shuttling issues greatly influence the electrochemical properties of metal sulfide anodes, especially for the cycle performance of batteries. The 3%Co-VS2 electrode exhibits excellent cycle performance and rate performance, which may be attributed to the formation of V-Co alloy nanoparticles during the conversion reaction. The favorable anchoring behavior on NaPSs constitutes the prerequisite for their rapid kinetics [40]. Therefore, to reveal the role of V-Co alloy nanoparticles on NaPSs, the adsorption test of Na2S6 was performed on the fully discharged state 3%Co-VS2 and VS2 electrodes (Fig. 4 a). After 48 h, the solution of 3%Co-VS2 and VS2 electrode showed transparent color and light yellow, respectively. The characteristic absorption peak of Na2S6 in the UV-vis absorption spectra of the corresponding 3%Co-VS2 electrode is lower, indicating that the fully discharged 3%Co-VS2 electrode has a stronger adsorption effect on polysulfides than the VS2 electrode, implying that V-Co alloy nanoparticles can strongly adsorb NaPSs. According to the recent study [41], the decomposition barriers of NaPSs are correlated with the adsorption energies, in which higher adsorption energies will result in a lower decomposition energy barrier. Therefore, it can be inferred that the V-Co alloy nanoparticles formed after Co doping can reduce the decomposition energy barrier of NaPSs and rapidly catalyze the reduction of NaPSs to Na2S, thus effectively reduces the dissolution of NaPSs during the cycle (Fig. 4b). In addition, DFT further calculated the formation energy barriers of different reaction paths, as shown in Fig. 4(c). Na2S/V is converted to Na x VS2 with a formation energy barrier of up to 26.03 eV. In contrast, the formation energy barrier for the Na2S + V → V + S reaction pathway is only 8.58 eV, which suggests that Na2S/V prefers to generate V metal and S element during the charging process. This irreversible transformation results in S gradually becoming active material during subsequent cycles instead of the original VS2. This further aggravates the shuttle effect of NaPSs, gradually resulting in rapid capacity decay and eventually electrode failure. After cobalt doping, the formation energy barriers of (V, Co)/Na2S → Na x VCoS2 and Na x VCoS2 → Co-VS2 are 6.49 and 2.87 eV, respectively, indicating that Co doping can reduce the formation energy barrier of the reaction path, and the two-step reversible charging process is more likely to occur. Thus, the in-situ formation of V-Co alloy nanoparticles in the conversion reaction thermodynamically reduces the formation energy barrier of the reaction pathway, is responsible for the acceleration of electrochemical reaction kinetics of VS2, and conversion of soluble NaPSs to the Na2S. 3.4 Kinetic analyses To further explore the mechanism of Co doping for the enhanced electrochemical improvement of VS2, a series of Na+ storage reaction kinetics analysis was carried out. Firstly, CV curves of 3%Co-VS2 and VS2 are examined at various scan rates from 0.2 to 1.0 mV s−1 (Fig. 5 a and Fig. S19). Based on previous reports, the current (i) and the scan rate (v) follow the equation below [42]: i = a v b . Values for b closing to 0.5 and 1 imply diffusion-controlled and capacitive-controlled processes, respectively. These b values of peak 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 were calculated to be 0.89, 0.77, −0.72, −0.98, and −0.99, respectively, indicating that the pseudocapacitive reactions dominate of the 3%Co-VS2 electrode (Fig. 5b). Furthermore, the pseudocapacitive contributions can be quantitatively calculated by the follow equation [43]: i = k 1 v + k 2 v 1 / 2 , where k 1 v and k 2 v 1/2 represent capacitive-controlled and diffusion-controlled process, respectively. The capacitive contribution percentages of 3%Co-VS2 electrode at all scanning rates are summarized in Fig. 5(c). The capacitive contribution percentage increases with the scanning rate increasing, reaching 97.8% at 1.0 mV s−1. The 3%Co-VS2 electrode shows higher capacitive contribution percentages than VS2 at all scanning rates (Fig. S17). The ultrahigh capacitive contribution for 3%Co-VS2 is achieved from the enhanced electron conductivity and enough activated Na+ sites, resulting in the improved electrochemical kinetic with extraordinary rate performance. EIS analysis of various samples (Fig. 5d) manifests that 3%Co-VS2 (51.2 Ω) possesses much lower charge-transfer resistance as compared to those of 5%Co-VS2 (53.8 Ω), 10%Co-VS2 (79.3 Ω), and VS2 (204.1 Ω), demonstrating the enhanced reaction kinetics of 3%Co-VS2. In the low-frequency region, the sodium ion diffusion characteristics of different electrodes were obtained by fitting Warburg coefficient (σ). As shown in Fig. S20, the σ of 3%Co-VS2 is the smallest, indicating its fastest Na+ diffusion rate. Fig. 5(e) shows the in-situ EIS test results of the 1st charge/discharge process of 3%Co-VS2 electrode. We focus on charge-transfer resistance (R ct), which provides some electrochemical information about the active material in different states of sodiation/desodiation [44], and its resistance changes are shown in Fig. S21. At the beginning of the discharge, R ct increases gradually due to the phase transition reaction induced by the multi-step insertion of Na+, and the resistance decreases with the formation of V-Co alloy nanoparticles as the transformation reaction proceeds [45]. Similarly, the charging process at 1.5–1.8 V observed an increase in the internal resistance of the cell, indicating its reversible charge/discharge response. It is noteworthy that the electrolyte resistance (R s) did not significantly change in all states during the charging and discharging process, showing stable battery operation [46]. In addition, the conductivities of VS2, 3%Co-VS2, 5%Co-VS2, and 10%Co-VS2 tested by four-probe tester are 16, 197, 182, and 147 S cm−1, respectively (Fig. 5f), which indicated that the appropriate concentration of Co-doping could effectively increase the conductivity, ensuring the fast charge transfer required in a high-rate charge/discharge process. Subsequently, the GITT was employed to characterize the Na+ diffusion coefficient (D Na +) (Fig. 5g). Details of the test parameters and calculations are given in Support Information. As presented in Fig. 5(h), during the whole process of charging and discharging, 3%Co-VS2 demonstrates a maximum Na+ diffusion coefficient of 10−7–10−9 cm2 s−1, which is about 6 orders of magnitude higher than VS2 (10−13–10−15 cm2 s−1). These results mean that the unsaturated sulfur edge defects and sulfur vacancies induced by Co doping are beneficial to reduce the energy barrier of Na+ migration and diffusion and improve the electrochemical reaction kinetics. At the same time, in the conversion reaction stage, the in-situ formed V-Co alloy nanoparticles can effectively improve the electronic conductivity, reduce the formation energy barrier of the reaction process, thereby effectively inhibiting the shuttle effect of soluble NaPSs and enabling an efficient reversible conversion reaction. 3.5 Electrochemical performance of SIHCs The fast pseudocapacitive characteristic, the high-rate and stable Na+ storage performance of 3%Co-VS2, enables it to be an ideal anode for SHICs with high power and long cycle life. The SHIC is assembled with 3%Co-VS2 as the anode and commercial activated carbon (AC) as the cathode (denoted as 3%Co-VS2//AC). Before constructing the SHICs, the AC was tested as the cathode with sodium metal as the counter electrode in half cells. These CV curves, GCD plot, rate performance, and long cycling of AC are displayed in Fig. S22, all of which indicate that the AC possesses the electrical double layer capacitance with fast and stable ion adsorption/desorption. Fig. 6 (a) shows the working mechanism of SHICs. During the discharge process, Na+ deintercalated from the 3%Co-VS2 anode into the electrolyte, while PF6 − is desorbed from the surface of the AC cathode and the charge process is the opposite of the discharge process. To avoid possible electrolyte decomposition and side reactions, the operating voltage window was optimized to 1–4 V. The optimized mass ratio of the anode and cathode is 1:4, according to the kinetic and capacity match of anode and cathode (Fig. S23). The shape of the CV curves (Fig. 6b) displays a slight deviation from the rectangle, and the GCD profiles (Fig. S24) present a quasi-triangular feature, indicating a hybrid energy storage mechanism. As the scan rate and current density increase, the contours of the CV and GCD curves remain essentially unchanged without severe distortion, indicating outstanding reversibility and excellent rate capability [47]. Self-discharge performance is also a key parameter to evaluate the commercial prospect of energy storage devices [48]. Fig. 6(c) shows the self-discharge process of 3%Co-VS2//AC SIHC. The result shows that the voltage of SIHC drops to 3.88 V after 100 h, corresponding to a self-discharge rate of 1.2 mV h−1, which is better than previous reports [48–51]. The Ragone plot of as-fabricated SIHC is illustrated in Fig. 6(d). This SIHC delivers a high energy density of 118 Wh kg−1 at a power density of 624 W kg−1. Even at a high power density of 31,250 W kg−1, this SIHC still delivers a high energy density of 62.5 Wh kg−1, which are superior to the many previously reported SIHCs. Furthermore, the 3%Co-VS2//AC SIHC also exhibits outstanding long-cycle stability with a capacity retention of 85% after 10,000 cycles at 10 A g−1 (only 0.0015% capacity fading per cycle), as well as almost 100% coulombic efficiency (Fig. 6e). This excellent cycling performance is highly competitive with other reported SIHCs (Table S3). These favorable electrochemical performances make 3%Co-VS2 a promising candidate for fabricating pouch-type SIHC devices. As indicated in Fig. 6(f and g), we fabricated the pouch cell-type SIHC could exhibits specific energy of 102 Wh kg−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and can cycle stably for more than 600cycles (capacity retention is 88.6%). The superior performance and cycle stability of the SIHC benefit from the fast pseudocapacitive activity and reaction kinetics of 3%Co-VS2, which ensures the kinetics and stability match between the two electrodes of SHIC. 4 Conclusions In summary, this work shows that the dissolution and escape of polysulfide is one of the important factors for the rapid decay of the performance of the conversion-type metal sulfide anodes. To solve this problem, a metal cobalt doping strategy was designed to induce abundant sulfur vacancies and unsaturated sulfur edge defects, reduce the diffusion barrier of Na+, and significantly improve the ion and electron diffusion kinetics. In addition, combined with a series of in-situ/ex-situ characterizations and DFT calculations, it is proved that the presence of V-Co alloy nanoparticles can reduce the formation energy barrier of reaction pathways, enhance the adsorption and bidirectional redox of NaPSs, fundamentally promote the conversion of intermediates, achieve a highly reversible conversion reaction, and ensure cycle stability and long life. Therefore, even at high rate current densities, the cycle life of the Co-VS2 anode for Na+ storage has been extended to 12,000 cycles (capacity retention: 90%). The SIHCs assembled with 3%Co-VS2 anode and AC cathode exhibit a maximum energy and power density of 118 Wh kg−1 and 31,250 W kg−1 and outstanding long cycle stability (over 10,000 cycles). Meanwhile, the fabricated pouch cell exhibits a high energy density of 102 Wh kg−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and can cycle stably for more than 600 cycles with a capacity retention of 88.6%. The significance of this study is not limited to the development of high-performance anodes for Na+ storage. More importantly, the mechanism of heteroatom doping inhibiting polysulfide shuttle is revealed, which provides valuable guidance for the design of high-rate and long-life batteries based on TMD anodes. coredata.dc:description: Sodium-based storage devices based on conversion-type metal sulfide anodes have attracted great attention due to their multivalent ion redox reaction ability. However, they also suffer from sodium polysulfides (NaPSs) shuttling problems during the sluggish Na+ redox process, leading to “voltage failure” and rapid capacity decay. Herein, a metal cobalt-doping vanadium disulfide (Co-VS2) is proposed to simultaneously accelerate the electrochemical reaction of VS2 and enhance the bidirectional redox of soluble NaPSs. It is found that the strong adsorption of NaPSs by V-Co alloy nanoparticles formed in situ during the conversion reaction of Co-VS2 can effectively inhibit the dissolution and shuttle of NaPSs, and thermodynamically reduce the formation energy barrier of the reaction path to effectively drive the complete conversion reaction, while the metal transition of Co elements enhances reconversion kinetics to achieve high reversibility. Moreover, Co-VS2 also produce abundant sulfur vacancies and unsaturated sulfur edge defects, significantly improve ionic/electron diffusion kinetics. Therefore, the Co-VS2 anode exhibits ultrahigh rate capability (562 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1), high initial coulombic efficiency (≈90%) and 12,000 ultralong cycle life with capacity retention of 90% in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), as well as impressive energy/power density (118 Wh kg−1/31,250 W kg−1) and over 10,000 stable cycles in sodium-ion hybrid capacitors (SIHCs). Moreover, the pouch cell-type SIHC displays a high-energy density of 102 Wh kg−1 and exceed 600 stable cycles. This work deepens the understanding of the electrochemical reaction mechanism of conversion-type metal sulfide anodes and provides a valuable solution to the shuttling of NaPSs in SIBs and SIHCs.
